I am new to this sort of software, and I was concerned whether simply accessing photos several times each month would put me at risk of running over the monthly GB alloted by by phone carrier. They're downloaded from the Cloud, right? And anytime you download from the Cloud, you're transferring data, right? So it makes sense that, if you look at your pictures frequently, just accessing Dropbox on your iPhone will explode your data transfer byte usage.
I would have thought this a basic concern to anyone who has to pay a carrier for their cell phone usage; but (a) I couldn't find any documentation on this, (b) I couldn't even get an answer on the internet, which shocked me, and, most egregiously (c) I couldn't get a response from Dropbox itself, despite begging them multiple times for an answer to this simple question.
I'm not about to use this product if it's going to send my phone bill through the roof, and I told Dropbox so. They couldn't care less. When you send them an email asking for help, they send you back an email saying, effectively, "We're terribly busy, but if you really need help send a reply to this email." Well, don't believe it. I've tried it twice, and after weeks of waiting not a peep.
Incidently, I am also unable to access the Dropbox forums, despite having an account. When I try, I am told that my email address isn't verified -- this, despite the fact that they sent me a boilerplate email asking me why I wasn't using their product (isn't that a laugh). They have an automatic troubleshooter for this problem, but it doesn't work, either. If I could access the forums, I might be able to get a response to my concern there; but Dropbox wasn't interested in answering my separate email on this matter, either.
I say without malice that the support for this product is about as bad as I've ever seen in nearly 30 years of working with computers. Don't expect any help with it from Dropbox. As soon as I can get an answer to this question about data transfer from one of their competitors, I'll be going with them.

Dropbox for iPhone and iPad both work exactly as expected. Any document that I place in the Dropbox folder on the desktop of my MacBook is automatically and almost instantaneously, depending on the size of the file, synced to my iPhone 4S and third-generation iPad. Third-party support with services such as CloudOn in particular makes iOS functionality even more excellent. Dropbox is by far the best personal cloud file service out there, and I certainly recommend Dropbox over SkyDrive and Google Drive. I have found both SkyDrive and Google Drive problematic and finicky, especially the Mac OS X application for Google Drive. Dropbox is always flawless, and this iPhone and iPad Dropbox application certainly illustrates this reliability.

Dropbox is extremely useful. Easy to access on any device or on their website. I've never had any issues with it and have been a user for years.

whenever i establish a relationship with a vendor who requires an email address from me, i give them an email address unique to just them. i give that email address to no-one else and, in most circumstances, i will never send an email _from_ that email address.
that is exactly what i did with dropbox.
i signed up for a dropbox account almost a year ago, on march 21, 2012. i immediately received the standard "welcome" email. over the course of the next nine months i received exactly three additional marketing-type emails from them.
then i started getting spam/phishing emails. on 19-feb-2013 i received an email saying my direct deposit had been disallowed; on 26-feb-2013 i received an email indicating new security was being put in place for ACH and EFT transactions; and on both 27-feb and 28-feb-2013 i received an email asking me to join a linkedin account. all four emails were phishing emails.
since i have never shared that email address with anyone, since i had never sent any email _from_ that address, and since the emails were all phishing emails, then one of three things has happened:
- dropbox sold, gave away, or otherwise shared my information with one or more dubious with parties.
- someone hacked dropbox's systems and stole my information.
- dropbox has one or more rogue employees who is using customer information for their own benefit.
i used dropbox's web form to contact two different departments about the security breach, and i also sent two email messages about the security breach from the email address i had given them but to date i haven't heard a single thing.
dropbox has a legal obligation to inform all impacted customers about any security breach. a security breach is what happened here and they are nowhere near fulfilling that obligation.
